Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s message glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, we’re leaving for the family trip tomorrow morning! Mom’s so excited.” I could almost hear her voice, full of hope that I’d finally join in without my usual excuses. My family had been planning this holiday for months, and I knew how much it meant to them—especially after all the times I’d missed out before. But as I glanced at my laptop, the reality of my other world pressed in. My team’s chat was blowing up with questions about the core module I was responsible for. The project deadline loomed, and everyone was waiting on me to finish the design so the build could move forward. I could feel the weight of their expectations, the trust they’d placed in my skills. My heart pounded as I tried to imagine letting either side down. I wanted to be the dependable sister, the reliable engineer. But right now, it felt impossible to be both.
